docs.title: The VOID Preservation
docs.text:
Welcome! This documentation is a technical reference for restoring, maintenancing, and preserving The VOID's games and hardware.

These documents are an attempt to condense years worth of knowledge strewn across various minds and Discord servers. What you see may be subject to change.

Legal

This documentation exists for historical preservation, educational research, and interoperability only. All trademarks belong to their respective holders.

docs.title: Games
docs.text: A catalog of technical knowledge for The VOID games.

docs.title: Hardware
docs.text:
This section documents hardware and props used inside The VOID, including proprietary and off-the-shelf devices.

Disclaimer

Not every prop used in The VOID will be documented here. For example, specific models of DMX fans, scent emitters, or tactile floor transducers may not be included.

docs.title: RAPTURE Backtop
docs.text: The RAPTURE Backtop is a proprietary Backpack PC / Haptic Suit combo created by The VOID in collaboration with Optimal Design (now owned by Deloitte).

docs.title: Variants
docs.text:
There are two variants of RAPTURE Backtop that were used in VOID Terminals.

"Flat Top" Not much is known about "Flat Top" Backtops. From what is known, these were used up until somewhere between mid 2018 and mid 2019.

docs.title: "Dome Top"
docs.text:
The latest, and final revision of RAPTURE Backtops. (rest of writing goes here)

Disclaimer

From here on out in this document, all info will be about Dome Tops. Nobody (that we know of) currently owns a Flat Top, thus we cannot document it accurately. If you have one, please reach out!

docs.title: RAPTURE HMD
docs.text:
The RAPTURE HMD is the connected VR headset intended to run in-tandem with the RAPTURE Backtop.

Disclaimer

Three versions of the RAPTURE HMD exist. This page will only cover the "RAPTURE HMD", which is the version used in all VECs after early 2017 containing a modified Oculus Rift CV1. Eventually, there will be documentation covering the DK2 RAPTURE HMD and RAPTURE 2K (curved OLED).

docs.title: Hardware
docs.text:
The RAPTURE HMD is a semi-custom VR headset designed to run in-tandem with a RAPTURE Backtop. It contains a modified Oculus Rift CV1, Leap Motion hand tracking sensor, OptiTrack Active Markers, and large stereo headphones with inbuilt volume controls. The custom shell changes the fitment of the headset from the standard CV1 and allows the front optic module to flip up for onboarding and safety.

[image of HMD, front / semi side view] [image of HMD, front view (LM centered)] [image of HMD, side view] [image of HMD, back view] [image of HMD, flipped up state] [image of HMD, interior showing lenses]

Aside from the custom shell and OptiTrack hardware, RAPTURE HMDs are nothing fancy. You can easily interchange parts between a standard CV1 and the RAPTURE HMD. Standard Rift CV1s with Leap Motion sensors attached were even used during development of games as shown in some promotional material!

docs.title: Miscellaneous
docs.text: This section includes miscellaneous info and technical jargon explanations related to The VOID.

docs.title: Glossary of Jargon
docs.text:
The VOID loves using lots of technical jargon in their marketing and internal communications. This page attempts to document some of the most commonly used terms.

Eventually, this will be in alphabetical order or something. For now, this is in order of memory.

docs.title: The VOID
docs.text: Yes, even The VOID is "jargon"! The VOID is a backronym acronym for The Vision of Infinite Dimensions. This information means absolutely nothing other than fun trivia.

docs.title: Dimension / Dimensions
docs.text: All VOID experiences / games are referred to internally as Dimensions. This can be found inside a Backtop's file structure, where the Dimensions folder holds all of the game files for each game.

docs.title: Traveler
docs.text: Refers to a customer / guest stepping into The VOID.

docs.title: Stage
docs.text:
The physical set where VOID Dimensions take place. These stages include OptiTrack tracking hardware, various physical walls and setpieces, props, DMX environmental FX hardware (fans, compressed air emitters, scent emitters, heat lamps, water misters), RAPTURE Gun holsters, and button panels. VOID stages are modular, meaning they can be swapped to the physical designs of another Dimension within a few hours.

Latest / Final physical design was made by TAIT Design. No public documentation of the partnership between TAIT and The VOID exists (aside from semi-private employee recountings) however TAIT is also connected to JUMP by Limitless Flight (seen here), a project founded by James Jensen.

3D render of a base stage, with no additional walls or props.

docs.title: Backtop
docs.text: A portmanteau of the words "laptop" and "backpack". The VOID originally had a trademark on this word, but it's long expired.

docs.title: Terminal / VEC
docs.text: In some public-facing communications (seen here), The VOID refers to their locations as "Terminals". Internally, a location can sometimes be referred to as a "VEC" (VOID Entertainment Center?).

docs.title: VOID API
docs.text:
Documentation for the VOID API and the tooling used by the games.

The information here reflects what we have discovered and verified (mostly through decompilation). This is not a complete reference! We document the functions and features that we use.

The VOID APIs evolves the newer the game. APIs and internal behavior may differ between games; some functions may be unavailable or behave differently in other games.

We have SDKs for the following games:

  • "NICO" (Nicodemus: Demon of Evanishment)
  • "WIR2" (Ralph Breaks VR)
  • "LookingGlass" (Jumanji: Reverse the Curse)

docs.title: Build Requirements
docs.text: Building this project requires a legacy environment. If you choose to build from source, ensure your environment matches these specifications exactly.

docs.title: 1. Visual Studio Version
docs.text:
• Recommended: Visual Studio 2017
  • Alternative: Visual Studio 2022 (requires v141 / 2017 Build Tools installed via the Visual Studio Installer).

docs.title: 2. Required Workloads and Components
docs.text:
Ensure the following are selected in the Visual Studio Installer:

Workloads

  • Desktop development with C++
  • Game development with C++

Individual Components

  • Windows 10 SDK (10.0.17134.0)
  • MSVC v141 - VS 2017 C++ x64/x86 build tools
  • Windows 8.1 SDK (Must be installed manually from the Microsoft website).

docs.title: Critical Setup (Required)
docs.text: The legacy Unreal Build Tool (UBT) is prone to version drift. It will often attempt to use the newest SDK on your system, which is incompatible for these games.

docs.title: Step 1: Force SDK Compatibility (SDK Hiding)
docs.text:
If you have Windows 10 or 11 SDKs newer than 17134 installed, you must temporarily hide them from the compiler:

  1. Navigate to: C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10\Include
  2. Locate any folders newer than 10.0.17134.0.
  3. Rename them by adding an underscore prefix (e.g., rename 10.0.26100.0 to _10.0.26100.0).
  4. Important: Remember to revert these names when working on modern projects or other engines.

docs.title: Step 2: Refresh Project Files
docs.text: You must regenerate Visual Studio project files after installing new components or modifying the SDK directory. Right-click the .uproject file in your file explorer and select Generate Visual Studio project files.

docs.title: Packaging the mod
docs.text: Because this project targets legacy dependencies, the standard "Package Project" option in the Unreal Editor will fail as it attempts to re-build. You must manually Cook the content and then use a standalone UnrealPak tool to create the final .pak file.

docs.title: 1. Cooking the Content
docs.text:
Before packaging, you must "cook" your assets to the platform-specific format:

  1. Open your project in the Unreal Editor.
  2. Go to File > Cook Content for Windows.
  3. Wait for the process to complete. Your cooked assets will be located in: [ProjectFolder]\Saved\Cooked\WindowsNoEditor\

docs.title: 2. Manual Content Cleanup
docs.text:
To ensure compatibility with the game and avoid unnecessary bloat, you must prune the cooked directory. Navigate to your cooked content folder and delete the following:

  • Engine/ (The entire engine folder)
  • AssetRegistry.bin
  • Delete everything in Content except for the Mods folder

docs.title: 3. Creating the .pak File
docs.text:
You will need the UnrealPak tool to package the cooked assets.

  1. Download and extract the UnrealPak utility.
  2. Drag your cleaned WindowsNoEditor folder onto the UnrealPak-With-Compression.bat (with or without compression doesn't matter).
  3. Rename the resulting .pak file to match the game's naming convention (usually WindowsNoEditor.pak).
  4. You will need to rename this pak to utils
  5. Place the pak file in the game's content directory to test.

docs.title: XVoid
docs.text:
So far, XVoid appears only once, within the Wreck-It Ralph game, alongside Void.

The reason for the name "XVoid" is unclear, but there are two prevailing theories:

  1. XVoid represents their newer system, with the "X" standing for "Extended." This API was likely created for use in future games, as some functions in older games seem to have been put into the XVoid plugin.

  2. Alternatively, it could have been an old plugin that is now deprecated, as it no longer appears in newer games like Jumanji, with most of its functions missing.

Disclaimer

As some functions are labeled without XVoid in games older than Wreck-It Ralph, we won't create separate documentation for XVoid functions (unless they are only seen in XVoid API), but we will indicate if a function appears in XVoid.

docs.title: Void Blueprint Utilities
docs.text:
Blueprint utilities are used throughout the games.

In more recent games, these utilities are typically part of the Void plugin API. However, in older games like Nicodemus, they are included in the main game modules.

All blueprint utilities will be documented here, as they often perform the same functions but may belong to different APIs. We will also specify the games in which they are found or not found.

docs.title: DebugJumpToScenario
docs.text:
Danger

This is based on a decompilation of WIR only, and it's internal functionality DOES vary between titles; exact behavior for other games with this function has not yet been confirmed. Additionally, it's no longer seen in the newer games like Jumunji.

Debug-jumps the active scenario to a matching Scenario. Believed to be used primarily for development and testing to force the manager to make a specific scenario active.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Requirement Details Return Type None Parameters Scenario (Object varies depending on game)

docs.title: Function Logic Flow
docs.text:
The function operates through the following sequence:

  1. Null check: Return immediately if Scenario is nullptr.
  2. Ensure array not empty: Verify m_Scenarios.Num() is greater than zero.
  3. Find matching pointer: Iterate m_Scenarios and compare each element's ScenarioPointer to Scenario.
  4. Set active scenario: If a match is found, obtain the FScenarioInfo pointer and call SetActiveScenario(Info).

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: • Scenario: Pointer to the Scenario. If nullptr, the function exits without side effects.

docs.title: Behavior and Edge Cases
docs.text:
• Success Case: When a matching ScenarioPointer is found in m_Scenarios, the corresponding FScenarioInfo is passed to SetActiveScenario() and the manager switches to that scenario.
  • Failure Case: If Scenario is nullptr, or m_Scenarios is empty, or no matching pointer is found, the function returns without changing state.

docs.title: IsEmulatorConnected
docs.text:
Warning

This is based on a decompilation of WIR only, but the same logic should apply to all games. This function has been observed in all games seen so far.

This function is a utility helper designed to check for the presence of an emulator. At the moment, we don't actually know what the emulator is.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Requirement Details Return Type bool Parameters UObject* WorldContextObject

docs.title: Function Logic Flow
docs.text:
The function operates through a simple validation and retrieval sequence:

  1. It attempts to locate the global instance of the VoidSDKManager.
  2. It checks if the VoidSDKManager instance is valid (not null).
  3. If valid, it queries the manager for a specific boolean setting identified by the key "emulator.present".
  4. It returns the value of that setting. If the manager cannot be found, it defaults to false.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: • WorldContextObject: A pointer to an object that belongs to the current World.

docs.title: Behavior and Edge Cases
docs.text:
• Success Case: If the SDK is active and the game is running on an emulator (like Bluestacks, Nox, or a mobile dev emulator), the function returns true.
  • Failure Case: If the AVoidSDKManager is missing from the scene or fails to initialize, the function returns false.
